title: Happy Mondays star Shaun Ryder branded a 'k**b' by his own brother
text:

Happy Mondays star Paul Ryder has branded brother and bandmate Shaun a ­fantasist “k**b” who has ­always twisted his melon.

Bassist Paul, 55, thinks it is time to set the record straight as the original 24 Hour Party People re-form for a 29-date greatest hits tour this month.

And he said: “Our Shaun should change his name by deed poll to Walter Mitty. I’m gonna need four years away from them all to get over it.”

Talking of the late Factory Records co-founder Tony Wilson, he said: “Tony told the world we were scum and that was how he marketed us.

(Image: Redferns)

“Sure, we took loads of drugs and had a good time. But Shaun went over the top. He started telling lies and spoofing me. He loves the limelight and hijacks history to make out he was first to do this, that, the other.

“For 30 years I’ve bit my tongue. But not any more. The tour is starting, our fans are back and people deserve to know my story.

“Yes, Shaun is a lyrical genius but sometimes I look across at him on stage and think, ‘What a knob.’”

Speaking from his home in France, dad-of-four Paul added: “There are countless stories he’s just invented. God knows where they come from.

“The wild tales of what we got up to recording our fourth album in Barbados were all myths and spoofs.”

Recalling his childhood with Shaun, 57, Paul says: “When I was three he pushed me off my bike and I needed hospital treatment. I still have the scars on my hands and it still makes me mad when I look at them.

“It was always going off between us. I was around nine when he took a psycho-swing at me with his new golf club and split my head open.”

(Image: Coventry Telegraph)

Paul shared a flat with Shaun and Mondays dancer Bez in their late teens, where they held chaotic ­parties. He said his brother also gave him ­brutal tongue lashings there – after one of which he “smashed him in the face”.

“He was in shock for months and left me alone. I worked out I had to leather him about every three years to keep our relationship in check.”

Paul also reveals it was him who gave the band their name. “Our first gig was 1983, in Salford.

(Image: Redferns)

"The next week, the Mondays were born. I chose the name. We’d sign on each Thursday and the giro might not come by Friday, so we’d have no money at ­weekends.

"On Monday the giro would arrive. It was the day for getting off your face.”

After their heyday in the late 80s and early 90s, Paul struggled with heroin addictions.

(Image: Redferns)

He says: “We couldn’t have Calpol for the kids. I’d drink the lot.”

His youngest son Chico was diagnosed with cancer aged ten.

Paul says: “I found myself coaching him on how to inhale cannabis vapour from a ­vapourising machine. My drug problems are well documented. I nearly lost my life. But it was cannabis that saved my son’s.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: Paul Ryder claims his brother Shaun is living in a fantasy world as the original 24 Hour Party People reform for a greatest hits tour
